dataObject.dc:description: Sept. 1989; photo provided by Dr. Moreau
size: approx. 90 cm TL; July 2000; Ålesund Aquarium, Norway

dataObject.dc:title: Maximum Size
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Size
dataObject.dc:description: 200 cm TL (male/unsexed; Ref. 1371); max. published weight: 96.0 kg (Ref. 9988); max. reported age: 25 years
dataObject.reference: Frimodt, C., 1995. Multilingual illustrated guide to the world's commercial coldwater fish. Fishing News Books, Osney Mead, Oxford, England. 215 p.
Cohen, D.M., T. Inada, T. Iwamoto and N. Scialabba. 1990.

dataObject.dc:title: Environment
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Habitat
dataObject.dc:description: benthopelagic; oceanodromous (Ref. 51243); brackish; marine; depth range 0 – 2000 m
dataObject.reference: Cohen, D.M., T. Inada, T. Iwamoto and N. Scialabba. 1990.

dataObject.dc:title: Climate
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Habitat
dataObject.reference: Cohen, D.M., T. Inada, T. Iwamoto and N. Scialabba. 1990.

dataObject.dc:title: Importance
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Uses
dataObject.dc:description: fisheries: highly commercial; aquaculture: commercial; gamefish: yes; price category: medium; price reliability: reliable: based on ex-vessel price for this species
dataObject.reference: Cohen, D.M., T. Inada, T. Iwamoto and N. Scialabba. 1990.

dataObject.dc:title: Resilience
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Reproduction
dataObject.dc:description: Medium, minimum population doubling time 1.4 - 4.4 years (rm=0.2-1.1; also Musick et al. 2000 (Ref. 36717))
dataObject.reference: Musick, J.A., M.M. Harbin, S.A. Berkeley, G.H. Burgess, A.M. Eklund, L. Findley, R.G. Gilmore, J.T. Golden, D.S. Ha, G.R. Huntsman, J.C. McGovern, S.J. Parker, S.G. Poss, E. Sala, T.W. Schmidt, G.R. Sedberry, H. Weeks and S.G. Wright, 2000. Marine, estuarine, and diadromous fish stocks at risk of extinction in North America (exclusive of Pacific salmonids). Fisheries 25(11):6-30.
Cohen, D.M., T. Inada, T. Iwamoto and N. Scialabba. 1990.

dataObject.dc:title: Vulnerability
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#ConservationStatus
dataObject.dc:description: High vulnerability (61.35), based on Lmax and K (Ref. 59153)
dataObject.reference: Cheung, W.W.L., T.J. Pitcher and D.Pauly, 2005. A fuzzy logic expert system to estimate intrinsic extinction vulnerabilities of marine fishes to fishing Biol. Conserv. 124:97-111.
Cohen, D.M., T. Inada, T. Iwamoto and N. Scialabba. 1990.

dataObject.dc:title: Distribution
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution
dataObject.dc:description: Northwest to Northeast Atlantic: Cape Hatteras to Ungava Bay along the North American coast; east and west coast of Greenland; around Iceland; coasts of Europe from the Bay of Biscay to the Barents Sea, including the region around Bear Island.
dataObject.reference: Cohen, D.M., T. Inada, T. Iwamoto and N. Scialabba. 1990.

dataObject.dc:title: Morphology
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Morphology
dataObject.dc:description: Dorsal spines (total): 0 - 0; Dorsal soft rays (total): 44 - 55; Anal spines: 0; Anal soft rays: 33 – 45; Vertebrae: 51 – 55. Light lateral line, curved above pectorals. Predorsal distance less than 1/3 of TL. Color varies from brownish to greenish or gray dorsally and on upper sides, becoming pale ventrally. Peritoneum silvery.
dataObject.reference: Cohen, D.M., T. Inada, T. Iwamoto and N. Scialabba. 1990.

dataObject.dc:title: Biology
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription
dataObject.dc:description: Epibenthic-pelagic (Ref. 58426). This species is widely distributed in a variety of habitats, from the shoreline down to the continental shelf. Cod form schools during the day. Cod are omnivorous; they feed at dawn or dusk on invertebrates and fish, including young cod. Cod spawn once a year, in batches (Ref. 51846). They are marketed fresh, dried or salted, smoked and frozen; they are eaten steamed, fried, broiled, boiled, microwaved and baked (Ref. 9988). The most important stocks are the Norwegian Arctic stock in the Barents Sea and the Icelandic stock. The populations around Greenland and Newfoundland have declined dramatically (Ref. 35388). Over 12 nucleotide substitutions in the 307 base pair region of the mitochondrial cytochrome b gene differentiate this species from Gadus ogac (Ref. 40214).
dataObject.reference: Coad, B.W. and J.D. Reist, 2004. Annotated list of the arctic marine fishes of Canada. Can. MS Rep. Fish Aquat. Sci. 2674:iv:+112 p.
Murua, H. and F. Saborido-Rey, 2003. Female reproductive strategies of marine fish species of the North Atlantic. J. Northwest Atl. Fish. Sci. 33:23-31.
Frimodt, C., 1995. Multilingual illustrated guide to the world's commercial coldwater fish. Fishing News Books, Osney Mead, Oxford, England. 215 p.
Muus, B.J. and J.G. Nielsen, 1999. Sea fish. Scandinavian Fishing Year Book, Hedehusene, Denmark. 340 p.

Carr, S.M. and H.D. Marshall, 1991. A direct approach to the measurement of genetic variation in fish populations: applications of the polymerase chain reaction to studies of Atlantic cod, Gadus morhua L. J. Fish Biol. 39 (Suppl. A):101-107.
Cohen, D.M., T. Inada, T. Iwamoto and N. Scialabba. 1990.
